organization.fullName: United States Naval Medical Center, Portsmouth

identificationModule.briefTitle: Preoperative Use of Pantoprazole for Prevention of Post Operative Nausea and Vomiting in Gynecologic Surgery
identificationModule.officialTitle: Preoperative Use of Pantoprazole for Prevention of Post Operative Nausea and Vomiting in Gynecologic Surgery

leadSponsor.name: United States Naval Medical Center, Portsmouth

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
The goal of this clinical trial is to see if pantoprazole (a proton pump inhibitor used for acid reflux/heart burn) can reduce nausea and vomiting after gynecologic surgery in women between the ages of 18 and 79.

Researchers will compare a placebo to the active medication.

Participants will be asked to take three pills around their surgery, two taken before and one taken the night after.

armGroups.label: Placebo
armGroups.description: This arm receives the placebo drug. This medication is taken the night before, 2 hours before surgery, and the night after surgery.

armGroups.label: Active
armGroups.description: This arm receives the pantoprazole 40mg tablet. This medication is taken the night before, 2 hours before surgery, and the night after surgery.

interventions.name: pantoprazole
interventions.description: Pantoprazole 40mg given the night before surgery, 2 hours prior to surgery, and the evening after surgery.

interventions.name: Placebo
interventions.description: Placebo given the night before surgery, 2 hours prior to surgery, and the evening after surgery.

primaryOutcomes.description: Postoperative nausea and vomiting compared between two groups using Visual Analog Scale
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From enrollment until their postoperative visit at 6 weeks

secondaryOutcomes.description: Measure the time from surgery until patients can tolerate oral intake.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: From surgery until first meal, usually within a few hours.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Undergoing elective gynecological surgery by either an open abdominal or minimally invasive approach (to include both endoscopic and vaginal). Procedure must be performed under general anesthesia.

Exclusion Criteria:

* Pregnant,
* Patients with gastrointestinal disease requiring ongoing medical management.
* Prior gastrointestinal surgery with the exception of diagnostic procedures, appendectomy and cholecystectomy.
* Patients with a history of H2 receptor blocker use, proton pump inhibitor use or other GERD specific therapy within 30 days of surgery.
* Any patient identified by their surgical care team as having a history of PONV warranting additional perioperative prophylaxis.
* Known r suspected malignancy
* Lactose intolerance
